{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3081811,"name":"James M Turner","username":"Legojam05","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/l/7ba0ec/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-09-13T20:38:30.839Z","cooked":"

In the off-season, our team wants to create a motor testing board that can test more than one motor at a time (example: prototype chassis). The motors we would be using are CIMâ€™s and Talons. We wont be using a Robo Rio, and we would be running it without code, so we would need some kind of physical control system. The simpler the system, the better, as we need to conserve money for FRC season.

If you plan to use CIMs (aka brushed motors) you can power those directly off a battery. A few teams on CD have guides for converting old drills into motor testers. Let me find you a link.

Edit: Team Spectrum comes in clutch once again:

Prototype Motor Controller from cordless drill Technical
Teams have been converting drills to be used for prototyping or testing motors for a long time. We put together a quick video yesterday showing an example of the simple conversion process. Any 12v brushed drill will work to control FRC brushed motors (not Falcons or NEOs). [PXL_20220531_221215153] [Prototype Motor Controller Build]

An easy way to control up to 6 motors wirelessly. Works with any motor controller (or servo) that accepts PWM input.

andymark.com

RadioLink T8S Wireless Controller & R8EF Receiver

The next generation of robot remote control is here. Want features? It has features, so many features, more than you can count! This eight-channel controller receiver combination works for any and all situations. Connect it via USB micro to a...

I usually power the robot side radio using something like this:

adafruit.com

5V 1.5A Linear Voltage Regulator - 7805 TO-220

Ah, the venerable 7805, who amongst us has not used this popular linear regulator? This big chunky regulator will help you get your 7-35V battery or wall adapter down to a nice clean 5.0V ...

Price: $0.75 USD

but a VRM or USB car adapter will work as well.
